Files are available at http://code.google.com/p/alufr-ros-pkg/, documentation at http://www.ros.org/wiki/nao.

stack.name: ros

description.p: ROS is an open-source, meta-operating system for your robot. It provides the services you would expect from an operating system, including hardware abstraction, low-level device control, implementation of commonly-used functionality, message-passing between processes, and package management. It also provides tools and libraries for obtaining, building, writing, and running code across multiple computers.

The ROS runtime "graph" is a peer-to-peer network of processes that are loosely coupled using the ROS communication infrastructure. ROS implements several different styles of communication, including synchronous RPC-style communication over Services, asynchronous streaming of data over Topics, and storage of data on a Parameter Server. These are explained in greater detail in our Conceptual Overview.

stack.author: Eric Berger, Ken Conley, Josh Faust, Tully Foote, Brian Gerkey, Jeremy Leibs, Morgan Quigley, Rob Wheeler

description.brief: Kinematic models for articulated objects (cabinet doors and drawers), including model fitting, model selection and visualization.
description.p: This stack provides software that can recover articulation models given 3D or 6D pose trajectories.
The articulation_msgs package defines messages and services for exchanging trajectories and kinematic models.

The articulation_models package provides several nodes for fitting and selecting kinematic models for articulated objects. We employ maximum-likelihood sample consensus (MLESAC) for robustly estimating the kinematic parameters, and the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) for selecting between alternative model classes. The learned model assigns likelihoods to observed trajectories, predict the latent configuration of the articulated object, projects the noisy poses onto the model, predict the Jacobian, etc.
The articulation_structure package provides a service for fitting and selecting the kinematic model for articulated objects consisting of more than two parts.
Several tutorials, example launch files and demonstration videos are available in the package articulation_tutorials.

stack.name: dynamic_voronoi

description.brief: Efficient computation and updating of Euclidean distance maps and Euclidean Voronoi diagrams on 2D grid maps.
description.p: This stack provides software to compute and update Euclidean distance maps (DM) and Euclidean Voronoi diagrams (GVD) on 2D grid maps.

The program is initialized with a binary occupancy grid map and computes the corresponding DM and GVD. When provided with points that mark newly occupied or freed cells, the DM and GVD can be updated efficiently to reflect the changes in the environment.

Details on the algorithms can be found in the corresponding paper. Please cite the paper if you use it for scientific work:
B. Lau, C. Sprunk and W. Burgard, Improved Updating of Euclidean Distance Maps and Voronoi Diagrams, IEEE Intl. Conf. on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS), Taipei, Taiwan, 2010.
See also http://www.informatik.uni-freiburg.de/~lau/dynamicvoronoi

stack.author: Boris Lau, Christoph Sprunk, Wolfram Burgard

stack.name: world_db_model
stack.description: world_db_model is a framework for creating and maintaining a consistent and persistent state of the world. The idea is to record raw sensor data in bags and provide the results an interface to spatially query detector results. The results of detector plug-ins are calculated on demand and cached in an sqlite3 database. world_db_model provides a core node that contains the basic functionality to load plug-ins, record data into bags and play them back and store detection results. Further, it provides a plug-in for recording the tf-tree which is essential for spatial indexing in the bags, and a library for the easy creation of detector plug-ins.
stack.author: Maintained by Lorenz Moesenlechner

stack.name: OIT

stack.name: common_msgs
stack.description: common_msgs contains messages that are widely used by other ROS packages. These includes messages for actions (actionlib_msgs), diagnostics (diagnostic_msgs), geometric primitives (geometry_msgs), robot navigation (nav_msgs), and common sensors (sensor_msgs), such as laser range finders, cameras, point clouds.
stack.author: Maintained by Tully Foote tfoote@willowgarage.com

stack.name: cwru_tour_guide
stack.description: cwru_tour_guide
stack.author: Maintained by Jesse

stack.name: pr2_controllers
stack.description: Contains the controllers that run in realtime on the PR2 and supporting packages.
stack.author: Stuart Glaser sglaser@willowgarage.com

stack.name: otl_nav
stack.description: otl_nav incluses otl_roomba: roomba interface by python. 2dnav_otl_roomba: roomba navigation using ROS navigation stack otl_map: map data of OTL Lab.
stack.author: Maintained by Takashi Ogura

stack.name: odor_tools
stack.description: This stack holds tools for mobile robot odor experiments.
stack.author: Gonçalo Cabrita and Pedro Sousa

stack.name: logging
stack.description: logging
stack.author: Maintained by David Feil-Seifer

stack.name: robot_model
stack.description: robot_model contains packages for modeling various aspects of robot information, specified in the Xml Robot Description Format (URDF). The core package of this stack is urdf, which parses URDF files, and constructs an object model (C++) of the robot.
stack.author: John Hsu johnhsu@willowgarage.com, Wim Meeussen

stack.name: pr2_plugs
stack.description: The pr2_plugs stack provides the low level actions for autonomously plugging the PR2 into a standard wall outlet.
stack.author: Maintained by Wim Meeussen and Melonee Wise

stack.name: bag_experimental
stack.description: Stack for developing and testing new ROS bag-related capabilities.
stack.author: Maintained by Jeremy Leibs

stack.name: motion_planning_common
stack.description: This stack contains motion planners and supporting infrastructure.
stack.author: Sachin Chitta sachinc@willowgarage.com

stack.name: p2os
stack.description: This stack provides the p2os driver supporting any robot that uses either P2OS or ARCOS firmware. This stack also includes urdf definitions for visualization and examples to control the robot.
stack.author: Maintained by David Feil-Seifer (dfseifer@usc.edu)

stack.name: colbot-ros-pkg
stack.description: Colbot experimental robot custom packages

stack.name: ros_pkg_tutorials
stack.description: ros_pkg_tutorials is a stack for teaching different aspects of ros-pkg.

stack.name: simulator_gazebo
stack.description: Wrappers, tools and additional API's for using ROS with the Gazebo simulator.

stack.name: webots
stack.description: Tools for using ROS with the Webots commercial simulation software.

stack.author: Maintained by Christian Bersch

stack.name: icreate

stack.name: engagement

Explorations in Engagement for Humans and Robots. Artificial Intelligence 166(1-2): 140-164).

stack.name: roslisp_common

description.brief: Common libraries to work with ROS in Common Lisp

stack.author: Maintained by Bhaskara Marti and Lorenz Mosenlechner

stack.name: object_manipulation
stack.description: Functionality for performing object pickup and placing, while avoiding collisions with the environment. This stack is designed to be robot independent. It contains a complete interface for pickup and place tasks, as well as general implementation of most of the needed functionality.
stack.author: Maintained by Matei Ciocarlie

stack.name: tabletop_object_perception
stack.description: One example of sensor data processing for manipulation tasks. Containts functionality for object segmentation, object recognition and collision environment management for manipulation.
stack.author: Maintained by Matei Ciocarlie

stack.name: cob_common
stack.description: The cob_common stack hosts common packages that are used within the Care-O-bot repository. E.g. utility packages or common message and service definitions etc. Also the urdf desciption of the robot is located in this stack.

stack.name: image_transport_plugins

description.brief: Plugins for specialized network image transport

stack.description: A set of plugins for publishing and subscribing to sensor_msgs/Image topics in representations other than raw pixel data. For example, for viewing a stream of images off-robot, a video codec will give much lower bandwidth and latency. For low frame rate tranport of high-definition images, you might prefer sending them as JPEG or PNG-compressed form.
stack.author: Maintained by Patrick Mihelich

stack.description: The perception_pcl_addons stack contains additions to the Point Cloud Library (PCL) such as visualization tools, tutorials and example code, and demos.

stack.name: pr2_mechanism
stack.description: The pr2_mechanism stack contains the infrastructure to control the PR2 robot in a hard realtime control loop. The main interface to packages in this stack is through C++, but it is possible to interact with controllers through a ROS API. While the stack is currently aimed at controlling the PR2 robot, it should work on most force-controlled robots.

stack.name: arm_navigation
stack.description: The arm navigation stack contains the action/behavior used to execute collision free motion planning and control for a robot arm manipulator. Included in this stack are the messages required for an action interface that can be used to specify and abort goals for the move_arm action. An implementation for arm navigation on the PR2 robot can be found in the pr2_arm_navigation stack.
stack.author: Maintained by Sachin Chitta

stack.name: orocos
stack.description: orocos: Open Robot Control Software, version 1.10. Version 2.x of the project is available as the Orocos toolchain ROS stack. The project's aim is to develop a general-purpose, free software, and modular framework for robot and machine control.
stack.author: Maintained by Ruben Smits

stack.name: erratic_robot

description.brief: Packages related to Videre Erratic mobile robot

stack.description: This stack contains packages that are used to interface with Videre Erratic mobile robot. These include the hardware interface driver, URDF description, 3D meshes, navigation stack configuration and launch files and keyboard teleoperation node.
stack.author: Maintained by Antons Rebguns

stack.name: vicon
stack.description: Vicon motion tracking system interface stack
stack.author: Chris Burbridge

stack.name: wg_common

description.brief: Common code for Willow Garage robots.

stack.author: Maintained by Eitan Marder-Eppstein

stack.name: sarkofag_robot
stack.description: sarkofag_robot
stack.author: Maintained by Konrad Banachowicz

stack.name: lse_arduino
stack.description: A stack for arduino related packages for ROS.

stack.name: physics_ode
stack.description: Open Dynamics Physics Engines for Simulation and Planning (Collision Detection).

stack.name: cob_apps

stack.name: nxt

description.brief: A stack for interacting with Lego NXT

stack.description: This stack has basic interfaces for interacting with ROS and NXT. The software in this stack is intended to run on top of the default NXT firmware provided by lego.
stack.author: Maintained by Tully Foote, Wim Meeussen, and Melonee Wise

stack.name: pr2_apps
stack.description: Basic applications for the PR2 robot
stack.author: Maintained by Wim Meeussen

stack.name: ias_visualization
stack.description: ias_visualization is a collection of visualization messages and accompanying rviz plugins
stack.author: Maintained by Nico Blodow

stack.name: vanadium_robots
stack.description: This stack contains configuration files, launch files, and application code for robots developed at Vanadium Labs.
stack.author: Maintained by Michael Ferguson

stack.name: visualization_tutorials
stack.description: Tutorials related to the visualization stack such as Marker tutorials
stack.author: Maintained by Josh Faust

stack.name: laser_pipeline
stack.description: Libraries from processing laser data, including converting laser data into 3D representations.
stack.author: Maintained by Jeremy Leibs

stack.name: urdf_tools

description.brief: Tools for use with URDF Models

stack.description: This package contains a number of tools for making, viewing and using URDF models.
stack.author: Maintained by David Lu!!

stack.name: pr2_kinematics_with_constraints
stack.description: This stack contains an implementation of kinematics for the PR2 robot arms. The implementation can currently compute collision free position inverse kinematics for the PR2 arms.
stack.author: Maintained by Sachin Chitta

stack.name: pr2_self_test
stack.description: Packages for running PR2 self-tests and bringup checks onboard robot.
stack.author: Kevin Watts

stack.name: ua_controllers
stack.description: This stack contains higher level controllers for the Wubble Robot, which generally depend on packages in the ua_drivers stack for interfacing with the hardware. Thus, packages in this stack provide a higher level of abstraction for Wubble Robot subsystems than ua_drivers.
stack.author: Maintained by UA Robotics Research Group

stack.name: rlrobot
stack.description: rlrobot
stack.author: Maintained by Sosentos

stack.name: ethzasl_mapping

stack.name: head_interaction_behavior
stack.description: head_interaction_behavior
stack.author: Maintained by David Feil-Seifer

stack.name: ndi_hardware
stack.description: ndi_hardware is a stack with a driver and example components/applications to use NDI hardware with a Linux based system. At the moment implementation for: the NDI Polaris (R) 3D optical measurement system
stack.author: Maintained by Dominick Vanthienen

stack.name: diagnostics
stack.description: Packages related to gathering, viewing, and analyzing diagnostics data from robots.

stack.name: ua_robots

description.brief: Contains URDF descriptions of UA robots.

stack.description: This stack contains URDF description files, 3D models, meshes, textures and configuration parameters needed for Wubble Robot simulation.
stack.author: Maintained by UA Robotics Research Group

stack.name: power_supplies

stack.name: pr2_doors
stack.description: The pr2_doors stack provides the building blocks and integration to allow the PR2 to autonomously detect and open doors.
stack.author: Maintained by Wim Meeussen
